content.description: Good rock, with the exception of the sharp crystals for the topout. The first line done here. A stiff move leads to several easy moves onto the lip, where an odd mantle solidifies the grade. Consider creative use of the feet to get off the ground...
content.location: To the left of the birch tree, begin with arms wide on a left-hand slanted crimp, and right handed crimp. Use some foot-voodoo to make the first move feel much easier. Perform an odd mantle using crystalline holds far back from the lip.

content.description: Start sitting in the cave on a sloper. Make a big move out left to a good lip, the are more holds over the bulge. Figure out the sequence for the top.
content.location: Down the hill about 200 yards from the spring wall. Best way to get there is to park at the lower parking lot, and the boulders will be sitting a top a hill. Other boulders are in the area just really not worth posting, good for warming up though.

content.description: Start sitting on the v groove under the boulder made a move up to a good sloper and gain better holds over the top. A right exit may merritt a grade harder.
content.location: The middle of the wall to the left of spring again. Pretty easy to spot the vgroove.

content.description: A line of perfectly cut schist edges starts with some funky beta to get off the ground. Begin on the left-facing gaston rail, somewhere around the middle. Properly placed feet make a tough starting move a little easier before trending up and right on great holds.
content.location: Further down the bands of schist from Spring Again (V3). From that problem continue following the bands of schist until you encounter this one, separated from the rest, before the slope dips into a large open area.

content.description: An okay, if sometimes wet, little route that starts just right of the namesake tree on an incut horn, with feet on the shelf below the rock. Drop into the horn and punch up into some crimps before performing an odd topout.
content.location: On the first band of rock encountered, start just right of the beech tree on an incut horn.

content.description: I first found these boulders in Feb, 2014 when some of the lines barely poked above the two feet of crusty snow. Bands of schist stick out of the hillside, some only 3-4 feet tall, and others approaching 15 make for interesting problems from easy, tall crystal-granite problems to short, fierce lines on clean-cut schist. Take your pick.
